questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 μm) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as Cystoisospora.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with Kinyoun staining.

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Cystoisospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round,  contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round, contains 2 sporocyst each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval, contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

 

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis.

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cryptosporidium species.

In immunocompromised patients, the infection causes severe diarrhea similar to cholera and require hospitalization.

The diagnosis is made with stool microscopy. The cyst wall and sporoblasts are dyed red with the Ziehl–Neelsen (warm) or Kinyoun (cold) staining methods. Both methods have good specificity and therefore are useful as confirmatory tests.

The treatment is fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: The test shown below, which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying ____________.
questions.solution:
The given image shows blood agar culture with bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin.

Among the options given, Streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin.

Streptococci belonging to group A are identified (presumptively) by inhibition of growth by bacitracin.

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Streptococcus pyogenes

Cutaneous infections/diseases caused by Streptococcus pyogenes

Direct infections of skin or subcutaneous tissue

  • Cellulitis
  • Impetigo
  • Ecthyma, Erysipelas
  • Vulvovaginitis
  • Perianal infection
  • Streptococcal ulcers
  • Blistering distal dactylitis
  • Necrotizing fasciitis

Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

Tissue damage from circulating toxin

  • Scarlet fever
  • Toxic‐shock‐like syndrome
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

Skin lesions due to allergic hypersensitivity to Streptococcal antigens

  • Erythema nodosum
  • Vasculitis

Skin disease provoked or influenced by Streptococcal infection (mechanism uncertain)

  • Psoriasis, especially guttate forms
  • Kawasaki disease

questions.text: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum?
questions.solution:
The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma venereum ranges from 10-30 days.

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The most common presentation is the inguinal syndrome, which is characterized by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Which is the agent used to treat the infection caused by the cestode egg in the image?
questions.solution:
The egg in the image is of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) and it is treated by praziquantel (5–10 mg/kg once).

The egg is oval, colorless, non-bile stained, and has a single shell with two distinct membranes. Inner membrane has two small knobs or poles from which 4 to 8 polar filaments arise and spread out between the two membranes. It is embryonated and the oncosphere has six hooks (three pairs of hooklets).

 

Life cycle of Hymenolepis nana:

Hymenolepiasis is the most common of all the cestode infections and is usually asymptomatic.

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except ______.
questions.solution:
Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by HTLV-1 (and not HHV8).

Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), is lymphotropic virus and is closely related to Ebstein–Barr virus (EBV).

Diseases caused by HHV:

  • Kaposi sarcomas
  • Vascular tumors of mixed cellular composition
  • Body cavity-based lymphomas occurring in AIDS patients (Primary effusion lymphoma)
  • Multicentric Castleman disease

questions.text: Identify the condenser in the following image.
questions.solution:
This is a modern compound microscope, and the condenser is located below the stage.

The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light from the illuminator onto the specimen. Microscopes with a stage condenser lens render a sharper image than those with no condenser lens.

The simple microscope was invented first by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the father of microscopy and microbiology. It uses 1 lens for magnification. The compound microscope, introduced by Hans and Zacharias Janssen uses 2 lenses, an objective lens and an eyepiece, to provide better magnification power than the simple microscope.

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of ________
questions.solution:
The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans. 

Candida species, when cultured, grow as oval, budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae. Unlike other species of candida, Candida albicans can also produce true hyphae or germ tubes. This can be demonstrated after incubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 90 minutes. This is known as the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon. This test is positive for Candia dubliniensis as well. Another distinguishing feature of C. albicans is that it produces large, spherical chlamydospores on nutritionally deficient media.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to foscarnet

questions.solution:
Resistance to ganciclovir most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene. 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a beta-herpes virus. It is the most common congenital infection. In adults, its disease is mostly subclinical (option C). An apparent CMV infection resembles infectious mononucleosis (fever, sore throat, enlarged lymph nodes and splenomegaly). It is the most common infection in the donor organ seen 1-4 months after solid organ transplantation. In immunosuppressed hosts, it causes pneumonia and colitis. 

Diagnosis is by PCR assays. Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts (option B) and can thus be cultured in them, although the virus is often isolated from epithelial cells of the host. The cultured fibroblasts show owl-eye inclusion bodies after 2-3 weeks. 

UL54 (DNA polymerase) gene mutations can confer CMV resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir and foscarnet (option D).

questions.text: Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. So, on SD plasma transfusion, which of the following infection is likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Solvent detergent plasma is a form of blood plasma made from plasma collected from many people which is then processed with solvents to try to get rid of viruses. HAV is a non-enveloped virus, and hence it’s not affected by solvent/detergent (SD) plasma.

Only the viruses with an envelope are susceptible to SD plasma destruction.

Hepatitis B, C, and HIV are enveloped.

Related Pearl: Enveloped and non-enveloped viruses

  Non-enveloped viruses Enveloped viruses
DNA viruses

Parvovirus

Adenovirus

Herpes virus

Poxvirus

Calicivirus

Chikungunya virus

Zika virus

questions.text: Plasma sterilization makes use of ____________.
questions.solution:
A variety of hydrogen peroxide gas–based processes that use plasma as part of the sterilization process are known as "plasma sterilization."

The mechanisms of antimicrobial action in these processes are primarily due to hydrogen peroxide gas (or condensed gas) and not plasma, although the plasma generation phase of these processes is known to assist in the breakdown of residual peroxide in the chamber load.

questions.text: Identify the organism below that causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells.
questions.solution:
Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).

E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes watery diarrhea which is self-limiting.

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

 Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

  •  Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  •  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island.

The image below shows an electron microscopy image of E Coli.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication?
questions.solution:
The given image shows generation of mRNA from negative sense RNA within the nucleus. This occurs during the replication of influenza virus.

Orthomyxoviruses (influenza virus) contain segmented (8 segments) negative sense ssRNA that is replicated in the nucleus. Stages of viral replication include the following: 

  1. Attachment, penetration, uncoating: The virus attaches to cell-surface sialic acid via hemagglutinin. It is then internalized by receptor-mediated endocytosis. There is fusion of the viral envelope and cell membrane, resulting in uncoating or release of nucleocapsid into the host cell cytoplasm. 
  2. Transcription and translation:  mRNAs are produced from nucleocapsids via a virus-encoded polymerase. This process occurs in the nucleus. The mRNAs thus produced are translated into viral proteins in the cytoplasm. 
  3. Viral RNA replication: The viral genome is replicated by the same virus-encoded polymerase involved in transcription. The negative sense RNA is converted to its positive sense form. The positive sense copies serve as templates for replication of the viral genome. 
  4. Maturation: The virus matures by budding from the surface of the cell.

questions.text: Which method of diagnosis is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image is of darkfield microscopy as it has a dark background with a refractile organism.

The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies.

Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallidum.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

Strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode known to cause human infection. It has both a free-living and a parasitic life cycle. Its natural host is man. The infective form to man is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, the larvae migrate to the small intestine. They molt twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). Thus, it is ovoviviparous. These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

The rhabditiform larva can also be passed in the stool. It may directly metamorphose to the infective filariform larva in the soil, or develop into adult worms. The free-living adult worms then pass eggs, which hatch and mature to form infective filariform larvae. 

 In Ancylostoma duodenale infestation, eggs containing segmented ova (not rhabditiform larvae) are passed in the stool. The rhabditiform larva hatches 2 days after the eggs are passed in the soil. 

Note: Based on the method of reproduction, nematodes are classified as follows:

  1. Oviparous - They lay eggs:
    • Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichuria
    • Segmented eggs:  Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus
    • Eggs containing larva: Enterobius vermicularis
  2. Viviparous - They produce larvae. e.g., Trichinella spiralis, Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi
  3. Ovoviviparous – They lay eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch immediately. e.g., Strongyloides stercoralis

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Cestode
Diphyllobothrium latum Plerocercoid larva Eggs or segments of the tapeworm
Taenia saginata Cysticercus bovis Egg
Taenia solium Cysticercus cellulosae Egg (for intestinal taeniasis ) / cysticercus cellulosae larva (for cysticercosis)
Echinococcus granulosus Egg Protoscolices and brood capsules
Hymenolepsis nana Egg Egg
Trematode
Schistosoma spp. Cercariae Nonoperculated Eggs
Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs
Nematode
Ascaris lumbricoides Egg Unembryonated eggs in stool

Ancylostoma duodenale

Necator americanus

 Filariform larva Eggs (in fresh stool), larva ( in old stool )
Strongyloides stercoralis Filariform larva Rhabditiform larva
Trichuris trichuria Embryonated Egg Unembryonated Egg
Enterobius vermicularis Egg Eggs from perianal skin
Filarial nematodes Third stage Filarial larva (L3) Microfilariae

Dracunculus medinensis Third stage filariform larva (L3) Adult worm
Hint: The infective and diagnostic forms are usually the same in the parasites causing autoinfection.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Northern blotting is used for the detection of RNA.

Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA and Western blotting is used for the detection of protein.

Northern blotting takes its name from its similarity to the first blotting technique, the Southern blot, named for biologist Edwin Southern.

questions.text: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of:
questions.solution:
The cook is most likely to be carrier of Staph. aureus.

The onset of food poisioning with in 4-6 hrs of food is mainly due to:

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Bacillius cereus (has no carriers)

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1–6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8–16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahaemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: The following image depicts:
questions.solution:
The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology.

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

  • Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
  • When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen, without adjuvant, intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
  • Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span, with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
  • The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.
  • Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

questions.text: A patient has complains of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. This organism is stained using Albert's stain which contains toluidine blue 'O' and malachite green. Both these dyes have an affinity for acidic cytoplasm as they are basic dyes.

Albert’s, Neisser’s, and Ponder’s stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules(Volutin / Babes Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Corynebacterium diphtheria appears as green-coloured bacilli with purple-blue-coloured metachromatic granules in cuneiform arrangement.

questions.text: Which of the following infection presents with mucus in stools and abdominal pain?
questions.solution:
Stools with mucus and abdominal pain are seen in infection due to Entamoeba.

Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis:

  • Acute intestinal amebiasis presents as dysentery accompanied by lower abdominal discomfort and flatulence. Stools usually have blood and mucus.
  • Chronic amebiasis presents with low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.
  • A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

Other options: 

Option a - Giardia is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, and flatulence.

Option c - Campylobacter presents with fever, pain and bloody or watery diarrhea. Stool contains leucocytes and blood.

Option d - Staphylococcal food poisoning is toxin-mediated and presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

NOTE: The genus Entamoeba has four morphologically identical species - E. histolytica, E. dispar, E. bangladeshi, and E. moshkovskii. E. moshkovskii which was initially thought to be non pathogenic has recently been shown to be a causative agent of non invasive diarrhea.

questions.text: A patient's plasma has high levels of interferon beta. He most likely has an infection due to _____
questions.solution:
Interferon-beta is secreted during infection due to viruses. 

Interferons are classified as cytokines. Interferons are non-toxic, non-antigenic and species-specific molecules. They are inactivated by proteases. They are stable at pH over 2-10, except INF-γ (labile at pH 2) and are non-dialysable and non-sedimentable.

There are three types of interferons - α, β and γ. IFN-α or leukocyte interferon is produced by leucocytes. It has antiviral activity, is immunoregulaotry and antiproliferative. IFN-β or fibroblast interferon is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells. It has antiviral activity and is thus increased in viral infections. It enhances MHC class 1 and NK cell activity. IFN-γ or immune interferon is produced by T-lymphocytes, NK cells . It activates macrophages, increases neutrophil function, enhances both MHC class 1 and class II expression and has anti-proliferative (anti-tumour) functions. 

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells?
questions.solution:
Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulator of naive T cells.

Naive CD4+ T cells are activated when they come in contact with two ligands - MHC class II and a costimulary membrane protein (eg: CD28). Both of these are present in antigen-presenting cells, the most potent of which is the mature dendritic cell. Other professional antigen-presenting cells include macrophages and B lymphocytes (option C).

Other options:

Option B: Follicular dendritic cells are functionally different from dendritic cells. They are not antigen-presenting-cells and do not activate naive T cells.

Option D: NK cells do not stimulate naive T cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is an immunologically privileged site?
questions.solution:
The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site.

Immunologically privileged sites can tolerate the introduction of antigens without eliciting an immune response. This allows a higher likelihood of graft survival, even without perfect HLA matching. As a result, an allograft can be placed in these sites without endangering a rejection reaction.

The unique immune tolerance in these regions is primarily due to the lack of effective lymphatic drainage, which prevents antigen presentation to the immune system, and the presence of blood-tissue barriers that restrict immune cell infiltration. Low vascularity contributes to immune privilege by minimising antigen exposure and immune cell recruitment. 

Examples of immune-privileged sites are the anterior chamber of the eye, cornea, testes, and brain. 

Note: Although part of the brain, the blood-brain barrier is absent at the area postrema, therefore it is not an immune-privileged site.

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient shows the following features. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
It is an obligate extracellular parasite
Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India.

questions.solution:
The given image shows the amastigote form of leishmaniasis located intracellularly in macrophages. Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite.

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sand flies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestation:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms,

  • The promastigote which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote which multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.

It lowers immunity, causes persistent fever, anemia, liver and spleen enlargement, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala azar dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults?
questions.solution:
Amikacin is not used in the treatment of typhoid fever.

Amikacin is an aminoglycoside. Despite showing efficient in vitro killing of Salmonella, first- and second-generation cephalosporins and aminoglycosides have proven to be ineffective in actual clinical cases.
